Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: University Maker Spaces: Discovery, Optimization and Measurement of Impacts

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Continued innovation is essential to national security and economic growth. It is crucial that engineering education move beyond teaching engineering science and analysis: engineers must design, create, and innovate. This collaborative project by Georgia Tech, Texas State University - San Marcos, and James Madison University will measure the impact of university maker spaces and identify approaches and guidelines for designing maker spaces. A maker space is a location where the individuals who have a passion for innovation can access resources needed to freely invent and build physical objects and prototypes. In response to the success of community maker spaces outside of academic settings, many universities are moving beyond traditional machine shops and building multi-disciplinary maker space design centers. This study seeks to understand and use these new environments to achieve long-elusive aims in engineering education such as improving student retention, fostering diverse learning environments, and promoting multi-disciplinary teams. Maker spaces also have the potential to positively influence females and minorities, who are driven to pursue engineering by opportunities for creative thinking and human impact. This work will also investigate the potential of maker spaces to positively influence females and minorities and there by broaden participation in engineering.

The maker movement underway nationally has the potential to transform university engineering education. The movement is primarily originating outside of the university environment. This project will measure the impact that maker spaces have on engineering idea generation skills, design self-efficacy, retention and minority/female engagement. The project has two major research objectives. The first is to measure the impact of university maker spaces at Georgia Tech, James Madison University, and Texas State-San Marcos. Impact will be measured through engineering design self-efficacy; retention in the engineering major; and idea generation ability. Impacts will be measured at two levels. The first phase of the project will use a randomly assigned experimental design to assess the impact of early engagement on females and minorities through a longitudinal measurement. In the second level, maker space participants will be studied via a comparison between extensive users and those with minimal exposure. In this project, segment snapshots and longitudinal measurements will be combined. The second major research objective will be to identify approaches and guidelines for designing maker spaces. Once the effectiveness of a maker space is shown, the questions of how to replicate it in other places and how to improve existing university maker spaces will be addressed. In this phase a cross-university study of maker spaces will be undertaken. Key features will be determined and may include how these spaces are designed, the people attracted, and hours of operation. Through interviews, surveys and collection of publications, novel approaches and effective practices will be determined and disseminated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As makerspaces grow in popularity, emerging in local communities, libraries, and at universities across the nation, the research field studying how making influences student learning and abilities expands as well. Data driven research focusing specifically on the impacts of academic makerspaces on undergraduate students is, however, sparse. This project aimed to quantitatively measure these impacts and identify other innovative approaches and best practices occurring at makerspaces around the nation. The data clearly demonstrates the benefits of makerspaces improved design self-efficacy and the fact that they provide an avenue for enhancing engineering education without significantly changing the current curriculum.  

At three very different universities, quantitative measures were used to compare the effects of makerspace involvement on undergraduate students. These measurements included GPA, retention, engineering design self-efficacy (EDSE), and idea generation abilities. Surveys and idea generation experiments were also administered longitudinally. University A surveyed students of all levels upon entering the campus makerspace for the first time. University B surveyed a cohort of students once a year in design courses at the freshman, sophomore, junior, and senior level. At University C, surveys were administered to students in design courses at the freshman, sophomore, and senior levels. The study design allows for longitudinal measurement of the same students and also the comparison across different universities.  

Results from the quantitative study showed that students involved in makerspaces generally showed greater engineering design self-efficacy (EDSE), meaning they were more confident, were more motivated, had greater expectation of success, and were less anxious regarding engineering design. At University A, students found to be voluntarily involved in makerspaces (i.e. used makerspace for projects outside of classes) reported higher EDSE scores in every category except for anxiety. At University B, sophomore level voluntarily involved students reported greater EDSE in all four categories. At University C, both freshman and sophomore voluntarily involved students reported greater EDSE in all four categories than students with no makerspace involvement. 

For the idea generation experiments, students were given a design problem and asked to come up with as many solutions as possible. The solutions were scored for idea quantity, quality, novelty, and variety. Freshman students with some sort of making experience prior to college or university (i.e. shop classes, experience with basic tools or power tools, experience with 3D printing, etc.) scored higher in idea quantity, but lower in quality. Women scored higher in idea quality.  Data from seniors was also collected. 

Avenues for increasing voluntary participation were also sought. At University C, students in a freshman level CAD course participated in an experiment in which one group of students was required to 3D print their project model, another group had theirs printed by a technician, and the last group did not print their design. Of the three groups, the self-print group had a significantly larger proportion of students become voluntarily involved in the makerspace afterwards. Receiving printed parts from the technician also increased involvement, but to a lesser extent.  This suggests that requiring students to use makerspace equipment on their own for class projects can significantly increase their likelihood of becoming voluntarily involved in the space. Furthermore, since makerspace involvement is associated with greater EDSE, adding some form of required makerspace use into the engineering curriculum could increase overall student involvement and be beneficial to the students' engineering design self-efficacy with very minor changes to courses.

Interviews with makerspace leaders were also conducted to gain insight on the common best practices of makerspaces across the nation. These results helped develop a list of common guidelines for starting and running an effective makerspace. This included things like: being open to diverse users and needs, inspiring students to seize opportunity, creating a culture based on student schedules, providing structure to empower students, and establishing proper protocols for the purpose, access, and usage of the space.

This study serves to inform colleges and universities of the benefits that students gain from makerspace involvement, as well as provide broadly applicable practices for academic makerspaces.  The findings of this study provide empirical evidence of the benefit of academic makerspaces to engineering students who use them both for classwork and for voluntary use. Furthermore, this study has presented one method for increasing the likelihood for students to become voluntarily involved with minimal impact on engineering curriculum. Finally, this study provides insights into the best practice for the creation and management of academic makerspaces from study of successful academic makerspaces. Ultimately, this study provides a significant evidence for the benefits of the inclusion of makerspaces in engineering education.
